div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definaitely engaged beforehand: Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monda.A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving inLondon at the very convenient hour of 4.56.p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fair is £22.9.11 Port Said to London vis Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leaves Suez for Aden and Bombay every WEdnesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was bright and cheerful, and the same conditions are promised to-day. The morning opens fine and clear with a light South breeze and steady barometer.
The new moon of Moharam 1324 will remain 24 minutes on the horizon after sunset.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA IMPROVEMENTS
div.p: The approaching completion of the new ses wall and the pavement and carriage road, 4 metres wide, that will afford Alexandrians no excellent an opportunity of enjoying the see air on the new premenade, naturally draw attention to the question of the disposal of the building sites on the extensive that goes by the name of the New Quay. We are informed that the plans for the new roads that will be constructed, and the plans into which the land will be divided and subdivided, are a' ready being prepared, and that very shortly the first portion will be ready for disposal. We regret t hear that in all probability it will b flared for sale and not let on building leases. Should this course be finally decided upon we feel sure that before very long it wjlj be recog- uised that a great mistake has been made — One that cannot be rectified in the future and mast be accepted for all time. This is so important a matter that pause may welt be given before the irrevocable step is taken. So valuable an area of building land ought never to pass out of the hands of its rightful owners, the citizens of Alexandria. Their interests are entrusted to the Municipality, a body supposed to represent them and elected by those qualified to vote, for that very purpose. The fact that the interests are committal to a small delegation and that the Press is excluded from the deliberations of this small and select party, should not be lost sight of; such considerations do not tend to increase public confidence in our City Fathers. Apparently they themselves are somewhat uncertain as to whether tiny are right in selling the land, for we are assured that only just so much will at first be offered as will provide capital for needed improvements in the city. Why, with the borrowing powers they possess, should not the building sites be let on lease and money be borrowed on the security of the ground rents? If this course were adopted there would be no necessity for even a portion of the property to pass out of the hands of the community, and the increase of value that must accrue as building after building is erected and occupied (at a consequent profit to the earlier investor) will allow of an increased rental being obtained at the termination of the various leases.

We, by no means, urge the letting of the land on such terms as would result in the surrender of all buildings erected oh it when the lease fell in, without compensation to the leaseholder. Such conditions are bad enough when enforced by private landowners, and probably the time is not far distant when in England the enfranchisement of the leaseholder will be legalised and the tenant no longer be left unable to claim compensation for the improvements made upon the property. A lease granted for, say, 50 years and renewable at the end of the term at a rental commensurate with the increased (or decreased) value of the property at the time at the leaseholder's option should on such favourable terms secure a good ground rent even from investors who as pioneers naturally hope for more advantageous terms than later comers would get in a few years' time. For many years their enterprise would be rewarded 'by the continually increasing value of their leas while no injustice would be done to them by requiring an increased ground rent when, at the end of the term, the leases expired. We know full well the difficulty of arousing public opinion even on questions vitally concerning the well-being of the citizens. Whether it is the fact that the business portion of the community, cosmopolitan as it is, is really Incapable of taking the interest that Englishmen in general feel in the local matters connected with their places of residence, or whether these foreigners feel that they have only a passing interest in the city which will cease when the) have made their fortunes and are free to return to their own lands, certain it is that no resentment is expressed, even at so glaring an injustice as the exclusion of the Press from the deliberations of the governing body. surely in a matter of the urgency of that which we have been discussing some strong hand should make its power felt, especially as it is understood that Lord Cromer is favourable to the adoption of the leasehold system, little as it is understood as yet in this country. What better opportunity could be given than the present for it to be successfully pat into operation.

While on the subject of the new quay we mast express the hope that on the reservation of space for the erection of Government and Municipal buildings which it is intended to make, ample provision will be made, not only for needs which can be foreseen as likely bat for others which may arise at no distant date. Too frequently public bodies have to pay dearly for a lack of foresight, and lost opportunities seldom return, as they have found to their cost While thinking it no part of their duty to provide for the requirements of future generations tiny neglect to consider sufficiently the possible developments of the immediate future, with the result that in a few years they fi id that they have lamentably underestimated the growth of the public wants. Alexandria is growing so rapidly that the most liberal allowance should be made not only for the extersion of the building it is intended to erect bat for the space required for others not at present contemplated. The area available is BO extensive that this can be done without in the slightest degree interfering with the fullest development of the property for many years to come while the reserved space would, from its situation, be rea i y disposed of at a greatly enhanced value, if needs be.

div.head: Small Dance.
div.p: There will be a small dance at Mena. House Hotel on Monday, 18 h irst.

div.head: Sudan Irrigation
div.p: Mr. Dapuis, Inspector-General of Irrigation for the Sudan, has arrived in Cairo on official business.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mails for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria at 3.10 p.m on Sunday.

div.head: Arrival of Transport,
div.p: The 88. Dners a rived at Alexandria, to day from Sonthampton with a number of reliefs for the British garrisons at Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: A State Bank.
div.p: There is considerable talk at the present time of the transformation of the National Bank of Egypt into a State bank.

div.head: Fire
div.p: Fire broke out yesterday in a baker's shop in Ragheb Pacha street and spread to a house on the first floor. The Fire Brigade promptly appeared on the scene and after an hour's work extinguished the conflagration. The damage has not yet been estimated.

div.head: The Egyptian Museum,
div.p: It has been decided to bar the windows of the rooms in the Egyptian Museum containing objects of great value and to station a guard in sach places day and night. These precautions have been taken in view of a recent robbery.

div.head: New Book on Egypt.
div.p: Sir Auckland Colvin has just completed a new book on England in Egypt, which will be issued almost immediately. As a former Comptroller-General of Egypt and Financial. Adviser to the Khedive, he has had peculiar opportunities of insight and study.

div.head: Murder at Alexandria.
div.p: Two Corsicans, French subjects, had a fight last night behind the French Bazaar at Alexandria. Both were armed with daggers and after a desperate encounter one of the combatants fell mertally wounded. His murderer escaped but as he is well known the police expect to arrest him shortly. The quarrel was about a woman.

div.head: A German Fete.
div.p: Mr. Hellwig, the German Vion-Consul at Alexandria, and Mrs. Hellwig have invited the members of the German colony to a fête on next Tuesday night on board the German S.S. Hohenzollern, in order to celebrate the anniversary of the silver wedding of the German Emperor and the wedding of Prince Eitel Friedrich, the second son of the German Emperor, which will take place on Tuesday, 27 h inat. The captain of the S.S. Hoben- zollern has kindly placed the vessel at the disposal of the colony for this fête.

div.head: Philoptochos.
div.p: We may remind oar readers that the great annual veglione of the Philoptochos Benevolent Society takes place to morrow evening, under the patronage of the committee, which consists of the following ladies :-Mesdames C. Sinadino (president), C. Rodocanschi (Vice-president), Emm. Benachi (Treasurer).C. M. Salvago, A. Zervudachi, Choremi, Ch. Ma- Vroscufi, J. Lagonico, M. Sinadino, A. Valassopoulo, A. Assimacopoulo. G. Jacovid's N. Tsamie, A Prazzica G. Zervadachi, A. Anas. tasiadi, D. Théodorach, Emm. ZerVudachi, and J. Sevas opoulo.

div.head: The Late Baker Pacha.
div.p: It appears that the late Baker Pacha, whore death was announced in yesterday's telegrams, was an old resident at Alexandria and retired many years ago from the service of the Egyptian Government. He was an officer in the P. and O. Company. During the Mutiny he gained a V. C. for carrying despatches in the face of the enemy. He held high rank in the Egyptian Police and resided at lex andria. He was cousin of the Baker Pacha, better known in England as Clonel Valentire Baker. "La Rétorme," in its issue of yesterday, is evidently under the impression that the telegram referred to Sir Benjamin Baker.

div.head: Pleasure Cruisers.
div.p: The most popular development of Mediter ranean tourist traffic during the last few years has taken the form of cruises and the general objective of these trips is that cradle of old world civilisation, the Levant. Every year more of these great pleasure cruisers visit Egypt and the Holy Land. Among this season's pleasure oraisers are the P. & O 8.8. Vectis, the Orient Pacific Line's S.S. Ophir and S.S. Orient, Dr. Lonn's Argonaut, the Hamburg-Amerika liners Meteor and Moltke, and Mr. Clark's specially chartered White Star liner Arabic. The tourists, who make use of these boats are mostly Boglish, Germans and Americans, especially the latter, who find these trips most convenier t Of course in such places as Palestine, where hotels and accommodation are comparatively limited-for example there are only about 700 beds for tourists at Jerusalem-it is easy to understand that from the 8th to 13th proxo. when there will be 500 trippers by the Arabic. and from the 12th to 16th proxo., when the Moltke will bring about 25 visitors to he Holy City, the leiserely inclined tourist would do well not to arrive in Palestine before the 15th March.

div.head:
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE
DISAGREEMENT ON VITAL POINTS
div.p: News regarding the Algeciras Conference to-day shows that there is complete disagree ment on the vial" points at issue. Both sides renain obdorate.

div.head: MR. BALFOUR AND THE CITY
div.p: The extraordinarily enthusiastic reception which has been accorded to Mr. Balfour in the City forms quite a distinct feature of the election.

div.head: THE MAHMAL
div.p: The Mahmal and its es ort hava left Mecca for Medina, All are reported well and no "incidents have occurred.

div.head: THE NOUR EL BAHR
div.p: The cruiser Nour el Bahr will sail from Suez for Akaba to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock.

div.head: OFFICIAL CHANGES
div.p: There is a rumour to the effect that Abdul Halim Pecha Assem, Director-General of the Wafks, will be replaced by Adly Pach Yeghen, Governor of Cairo, whose place will be taken at the Gouvernorat by Hassan Paoha Radwan, Mondir of Gharbieb. Nothing, however, will be decided until the return of H.H. the Khedive.

div.head: DELTA LAND COMPANY
div.p: This company has now acquired the whole of the property formerly held by the Société des Moulins, including all their freehold property in Cairo, Alexandria, and the provinces. The price to be paid is £150,0 0, the payments being spread over a certain period.

The Delta Land Co. has been fortunate in obtaining the services of Major Le Breton as a member of the London Board and also those of Harari Pacha, who, with Mr. Williamson, is now a member of the Egyptian Board.

It is ramoured on the Bourse that the Delta Land Company has absorbed the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited. The shares of the latter company are to be taken at the rate of five shares to one share in the Delta" Land Company.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: The new steam boring machines having arrived in the Oases more rapid progress will now be made with water-boring; good flows. are being obtained. Excellent survey progress has been made.

The cultivations are doing well. The agrionltaral chemist reports that "the wheat at B Deir is very uniform in growth, shows a healthy olour, and gives promise of a very good crop indeed." Upwards of 1,000 date palms have been planted.
A new deposit of fibrous sulphate of alumi has been located at Nadura, a few kilometres north of Khargeh village.
One of the Corporation's prospectors has discovered some old workings, which are being investigated.

div.head: EGYPT AND SUDAN MINING SYNDICATE
div.p: The report shows that, after taking into Acount all the receipts and payments singa September 30, 1904, there remained a credit balange of £19,090. After the distribution of shares of the Sadan Gold Field the ayadicate retsins in that company 51.671 fully-paid shares, in addition to which it hold- 20. 00 partly-paid shares, on which 10. per share had at September 30. last been paid. Other share interests held by the syndicate consist of 5,000 fally paid and 5,496 partly-pail shares of the Dreheib and African Syndicate and 5 700 fully paid and 5,000 partly-paid shares of the Saskin Mining Syndicate. Upon the syndicate's concession in Egypt operations have been continued during the past year at the two centres Dangash and Barrahme. The Negem Mine is one which, with the continuance of good prospects, shoald pre-ently be handel over to a new company with the requisite ospital to develop it. The Sadan Gold Field continues to actively develop the Om Nabardi Mine. The directors understand that the raporta from the engineer in charge of the prospecting operations on the Dareheib proparty are to the effect that numerous and extensive old workings exist upon it, and that the indications are decidedly promising.

On Thursday another paner chase was held at Mena House Hotel. There was a very large field. This time the hares were allowed only five minutes start. The chase lay to the right of Mena, np the Pyramids road, crossing below the excavations on to the Sakkarah road, then on to the high desert for two or three miles, then down to the flat land, through the Mena village and home. The hare were sighted soon after the start and artern chase took place, the hares winning by about 150 yards. A cricket match will be played on Saturday at 3 p.m. at Mens Honse and on 8 nd-y Bra cal Band will perform both at luncheon and in the afternoon in the pleasant hotel grounds.

div.head:
AGRICULTURAL BANK
DIRECTORS' REPORT FOR 1905.
VERY SUCCESSFUL YEAR.
div.p: The directors report that the net profits of the bank for the financial year 1905, amount to £302, 285 145. From this amount there has to be dednoted: the service of the debentures is ned £96 02.1.0; the provision for the reserve fund, £5 790.4 6.total, £121,992.15 6, leaving £18292 18.11. And there has to te forther denoted dividend on £1.250.000 preferred shares, £46 12-.10.11 and 5% to the National Bark of Bgyp", £92.5 10, total, £55,15 .169, leaving £125, 41.2 2. which is. available for distribution of dividend on ordinary and deferred shares. The ordinary hsres have to rece've in the first instance dividend at the rate of 5% per annum, making £62,000.0.0. The balance of £63,141.2.2 is available to the extent of one half or £31,570.11.1 for further dividend on the ordinary shares and to the extent of one half or £31,570.11.1 for dividendy on the deferred shares.

The amounts available for dividend on the ordinary shares (first issue of 248 000 shares) for the year are as follows: balance from 1904,- £ 3.119; for dividend at the rate of 5% per ainum, £62,000.0.0; further amount available, £31,570.11.1; total, £93,701.2.10. The directors propose a dividend at the rate of 7% per annum for the year 1905 on the 218,000 ordinary shares of the first issue, amounting to £9,000.0.0, and to carry forward the balance of £701.2.10.

The amounts available for dividend on the deferred shares are as follows balance from 1904, £42.5.6; further amount available, £31,570.11.1; total, £31,612 16.7. The directors propose a dividend at the rate of £15.15.0 per share, amounting to £1 500.0.0, and to carry forward the balance of £112 16 7.

Only the interest actually recovered during any financial year can. be taken into account in making up the balance sheet. According'y only the interest actually collected viz: £432,717.9.11, has been carried to the credit of profit and loss account for 1905, whereas the interest acorned amounted to £89,627.15.6 in addition to this amount.

At the end of 1905 the overdue loans for the year amounted to £68,400 and the overdue interest to £48,660 The greater part of these arrears was outstanding in the Behera province and in the northern parts of Ghar ieh and Dakahlieb. Of this amount over LB. 30,000 has been collected by the Bank up to Feb. 8th. Owing to the lateness of the cotton drops in these parts the payment to the fellaheen against sale of their cotton was naturally delayed and hence the bank was late in collecting its money. The directors are glad to be able to report that the work of the bank has. continued to increase steadily, £37.960 having been put out in loans during 1905 against £2,497.300 in 1904. The total number of loans put out in 1905 was 106,373 and the total number outstanding on the 31st December 1905' was 185,530, amounting to over £5,900 OCO, as against 134.207, amounting to a little over £1.000.000, on the 31st December 1904; of these 185.530 21,29 are A loans and 163,701 B loans. The following statistics of loans put out during the year may be of interest:

The average of the small loans is L.E. 8. 4

and the average of the larger loans L.B. 42. 1. In addition to the £625, CO of the 31% bonds is-ued in January 1905 the whole of the reminder of the preferred shares has been placed during the year, thus conpleting the issue of the £5,0 0,0 0 of capital authoris ed in 1904. At the extraordinary general meeting of the bank on the 18th of May, 1905, it was resolved to increase the hare cxpital to £3,740,000 by the issue of 24,0 0 new ordi- nary shares of £5 each and to increase the debentare capital from £, 00,000 to £6,570,00. This was duly sauctioned by the Government, subject to the condition that from the beginning of the year succeeding that at the end of which the loans outstanding should have resched L.E.7,000,000 the maximum rate of interest charged to fellaheen should be reduced-to 8% for both old and new loans. The new. ordinary shares were issued pro rata to the original shareholders at par in October and will rank equally with the old shares from January 1st of this year. The board have to announce with the greatest sorrow, and with a deep sense of the loss the bank has sustsired, the sad death of Sir Elwin Palmer, Governor of the National Bank of Egypt and President of the Agricultural Bank of Bgypt. to which institutions his great capacity and untiring energy were devoted. They wish to record their appreciation of the services of the whole staff at the headquarters of the bank and of the agents in the provinces.

div.head:
CAIRO CHARITY BAZAAR
A GREAT SUCCESS
STALLS LARGELY PATRONISED
div.p: All yesterday morning an energetic bevy of Cairo ladies were busying themselves in the large multi-coloured tent erected for the great annual Fête de Bienfaisance. Light stalls of trellis wood had been erected inside the canvas walls, and trails of bignonia, roses and other lovely flowers had been entwined round the stalls set out with all their tempting good... In the centre stood the circular kiosk ablaze with gorgeous flowers which shed their sweet ness through the air, in one corner was displayed a plethora of dainty hats, surrounded by a host of envious and perplexed femininity. Two stalls appealed to lovers of children and the tiny tots themselves, one reserved for general toys and the other given over entirely to a beauty show of surely the sweetest dolla that ever gladdened a child-mother's eye. Girl dolls, boy dolls, fairy dolls, and baby dolls were hanging there: many a nursery family will be richer for the addition of one or more of these welcome little strangers. At the end of the tent appeared the well-stocked buffet, with inscriptions banging round to reassure the timid that P.T. 5 would buy them the cup of tes or coffee or stronger drink for which their thirsty souls hankered. For those not averse to trying their lack there were the tables given over to the endeavours of the p tit chevaux and tourniquet, simple amusements surely but always certain to be well patronized. Objets dart and bric-a-brao of all sorts could be found at various corners, pretty pottery, and silken bags and tea ocsies and the like Enor mous lam abades, lacky charms, bits of dainty silver, le dernier cri in belts and bookles, useful housewives, and a thousand and one other seductive trifles hang in close proximity, and all of the beat and fairest of Cairo who were not among the tireless sellers were to be found among the eager crowd who came to leave their money to the advancement of the various charities.

Money changed handa quickly during the afternoon, though we noticed more than one rueful face when the smiling ladies pooketed the money tentatively offered them with no thought of returning the change due to the boyers. It must have been hard work to refuse the advances of the pretty flwer-sellers as they be-ieged the brave men who entered alone and unprotected. Prince Mohamed Aly and Prince Said Halim were fair game and when last. notioad were being hauled off in triumph to the tea tables, by the daintiest and trimmest of serving girls in a short stiff silk frook of pale pink with fiohn at her neck, and an apology for a cap amid her curls. The ladie of the harem paid an early visit to the bazaar before the general public were admitted, and from what one saw by half-past four there would not be much left on the stalls by closing time. The hat stall, presided over by Lady Mollwraith, Mrs. Carton de Wiart, and Mme J. Cattani, was especially well patronized, and there were many competitors for the dainty and chic chapeau which might have been sold two or three times over. If these ladies would only start a salon of their own we fear the profesional milliners of Cairo would have no hing more to do. The crowd around the petit chevaux table quite justified its being. Mne de Martino persuading many people to try their luck, and the tables doing the rest.

div.head:
2nd CO. R. ENGINEERS
ANNUAL DANCE
div.p: On Wednesday evening (writes a correspondent) a very merry party met át Kasr-el-Nil, on the occssion of the Sappers' first annual dance. The attendance was good, and at no time was the room too crowded. Everybody Reeped in the very best of spirits. The very latest dances were instituted and quite caught on. Sapper Newton took a prominent part in assisting the band, and helped to make things" most enjoyable with his "popular airs." On- has to look very far back to the last dance given by the Sappers; in fact, this was, I think, the maiden effort of the 2nd Company in Cairo. The organisers are to be congratulated on the success of their efforts. Dancing continued till 4 a.m on Thursday. The M. C. and his committee deserve great praise for the able manner in which everything was carried out. It was very noticeable that not one lady was allowed to "wallflower" a single dance, Everybody seemed to bave come to dance, and dance they did; and when the time came to break up all were of the opinion that a most pleasant and enjoyable evening had been spent, and trasted it would be the forerunner of many another.

div.p: By kind permission of Lt. Col. R.C.C. Cox. commanding, and officera 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fasiliers, the band will perform the following prozramme of music on the terrace, Sheph ard's Hotel, on Friday afternoon, from 4 to 6 p.m. :-

div.head:
THE HELOUAN SENSATION
FLIGHT OF ASSAILANT
HE SENDS THREATENING LETTER.
div.p: The name of the Spanish subject who at tacked Dr. W. von Grabowski, of the Villa Savoy Pension, near the railway station on Mouday, is Autoine Sancho. It appears that he had been engaged as cook by the month, and that he left before the end of his term. When he met Dr. Grabowski on Monday be demanded payment for twenty-three days, and upon being refused unless he finished his month or provided a substitute, committed the assault. In the afternoon, he seems to have gone to Mr. Mortimer, the Spanish Consul in Cairo, to whom he said that, having failed to get his money from his former employer, he was compelled to go immediately to Port Said in order to obtain a situation. He was upplied with a ticket and left. presumably for Port Said. Later on the Spanish Consul res ceived a communication on the matter from the Austrian Consul, Dr. Grabowski being an Austrian subject, and steps have been taken by the Spanish Consul to arrest the man.

Dr. Grabowski, after the assault, received a letter, dated at Cairo, in which Sanoho said that he was sorry he had done so little injury to him, but that if he were sent to prison, he hoped to come out again one day and to do the same thing again, or even more, unless his money were sent to the Spanish Consul.

Dr. Grabowski, who is well known in South Africs and in other parts of the world, is a. gentleman well on in years, and is blind of the right eye, which he lost in the Transvaal War in helping the British army. The blow was delivered him by his assailant on the right side of his face,, and caused an ugly wound. The injury was medically attended to, and we are pleased to understand that Dr. Grabowski is getting on better than expected after such a serious attack.

div.head: FRENCH BALL IN CAIRO
div.p: That the French charity ball would be a great success was certain, but even the most optimistio must have declared on Tuesday night that his expectations fell short of the truth. The committee had wrought wonders, the new theatre in Sharia Tigrane Pacha was Rate and as commodious as any theatre could be that was invaded by over 5,000 young, people armed to the teeth with confetti and serpentines and obviously determined to enjoy themselves.

At 9.30 p.m. the theatre was ready for the invasion, lit up and decorated, and at 10 p.m., the crowd poured in, overwhelmed the cloakroom, and bore down the resistance of the attendan's. Dominoes and costames followed one another in quick succession, the boxes began to fill, and at 11 p.m. the "Marseillaise" announced the arrival of M. de la Boulinière, who was accompanied by Mme de la Boulinière and her daughters. In the same loge were M. and Mme Barois, M. de Valdrôme, M. du Chaffault, and other members of the personnel of the French Agency and Consulate. The Princes of Orleans passed the greater part of the evening in the French Minister's box and to jadge from the confetti showers that issued therefrom enjoyed themselves hugely.

By midnight the theatre was packed-one breathed confetti and straggled with serpentines till exhausted. Then to the buffetand then back to the ballroom with renewed Alan. The members of the ommittee multiplied themselves-if the Gallicism may pass-deciding on prize-winners, hurling confetti, managing the tombola, and leading on the crowd of masks and dominoes. When the time for the prize-giving came the judges must have trembled every type of costume, male and, female, was represented, but the charming Roumanian peasant girl who won the first or ze was unquestionably the most picturesque. figure of the evening. An Andalusian was second, and had "highly commended's" been given hundreds must have won them.

At 4 a.m. the ball ended and the street oleaners and ghaffirs gaped at the returning dominoes. As to the financial statistics of the evening it need only be said that the net profits reached the sum of 45,000 francs. The social statistics must be incomplete-a column would not hold the names of a twentieth of those present. We need only mention H.H. Prince Fouad, Prince Antoine and Prince Louis d'Orleans, the Marquis and Marchioness. Salvago Raggi, Hon. Mr. Iddings, Baron and Baroness Rucker Jenisch, Baron Max von Oppenheim, Countess Grote, M. and Mme Maurice Cattani Bey, Adly Pacha Y ghen, Omar Bey Sultan, Ali Bey Chahin, Harari Pacha, M. ad Mme De Martino Pacha, Me. and Mme Carton de Wiart, Mr. F. T. Bowlatt, Abani Pacha, Fourneron Bey. Brewster Bey, Me. St. Privat Idris Bay Ragheb, Nangovich Bey, M. and Mme Widal, M. Caneri, Chélu Bey, Osman Bey Cherif, M. Gianaolis, M. Moise Cattani, Da Corogas Bay, M. and Mme de Vries, M and Mme Bertbe Dejean Bey, Cos éri Bey, M. Gnetin, Rannt Bay Labit, M. Zivy, etc., etc. The thanks of the European community are due to the committee in partionlar and the French colony ia general for a delighttal evening.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
H.R. H. Princesse Louise, Daches of A gyll, and suite are expected at the Chesireh Palace on Monday, 5th prozo

A very significant interest attaches to the visit to Egypt of the Archduke Joseph Ferdinand of Austria, who is due to arrive at Alexandria by the Austrian Lloyd steamer from Prieste on Monday next. He is the son of the Grand Duke of Tuscany and was born on the 24th May, 1851. In view of the strained rela tions existing between Austria and Hungary, the Arohdake, who is in command of the Hassar Regiment quartered in Budapest, has obtained leave of absence for eight weeks in erder, it is stated, that he may not be obliged to take part in any military measures which may be decided upon against Hungary....
H.H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg har engage ed a adite of rooms at Ghesireh for fort night's stay from March 12.
Colonel and Lady Susan Trueman, who were married last December, have now gone to Egypt, and intend to remain away for about six weeks.
Mr. and Mrs. Brodrick and Miss Sybil Brodrick are proceeding as far as Khartoum,

Abdel Halim Pacha Assem, Director-General of the Wakfs Administration, will shortly retire on pension and it is expected that his successor will be chosen by H. H. the Khedive soon after his return from Siwa.
The Count de Galaza de Santa Clara arrived from Europe yesterday and took up his resi dence at Mena House Hotel.
Sir Stephen Mackenzie has arrived at AssoUAD.
Aziz Pasha Istet left yesterday for Rome, where be will represent the Egyptian Government at the Agricultural Conference. He is expected to return here in twenty days.
M. Charmes leaves for France on the 26th inst.
M. and Mme Brieux are on their WAY to Upper Egypt and are now staying at Minich,

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Wednesday: Hon. St. John Brodrick, Mr. Watt and party of 3, Mr. Kay, Mr. Moore, Col. Yardlay, Mr. Nordborst, Miss Mouro, Miss Kay, Mt, Hernann Sauter, Mr. Gill, Mr. Robert Vihlein, Mr. Troman, Mr. Shepheards, Mr. Moy, Capt. div.head: OFFICIAL TRAINING
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF TE EGYPTIAN GARETTE Sir, The refusal of Chitty Bey to accept the Governorship of the National Bank of Egypt on the ground that he had had no experience of banking busires,has led your correspondent "Common Sense" to hasard the theory that officials in Egypt require a special training before being called upon to fill important posltions. The writer of the letter on this subject, which appeared in your columns on Wednesday, quotes a statement of Sir Oliver Lodge in support of the position he takes up, to the effect that the art of government should not continne to be the one department of human activity for which no special training was sup posed to be necessary. This standpoint is utterly ridiculous in my opinion, and especially so in Egypt, where the principle that a special training is unnecessary for official positions har, as every one knows, produced the most satisfactory results. There is not a Cabinet in Burope, where officers of State have not taken many and varied positions and filled them with conspicuous success. Even so in Egypt the Anglo-Egyptian official has been transferred from one department to another with, I think I may say, very satisfactory results, and it would not be difficult to adduce instances in the present Egyptian Administration where very beneficial consequences have ensued. Caption oritics, who venture to assert that posts are given by favouritism to untrained men, mus confess that the administrative machine rane with remarkable smoothness and that there is really little to complain of. We are much afraid that the arguments advanced by your correspondent "Common Sense" savour o Little Englandism and that be speciously brings forward his plausib'e theory as to the necessity of some training for officials in Egyp not for the benefit of his fellow men but solely as an opportunity for venting his disconten with a system of government that, however im perfeót, has successfully surmounted, appar ently insuperable difficulties and brongh Bgypt to an extraordinary pitch of prosperity.- Yours, eto.,

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the mostdelightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
